newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines' Ramos back to hospital for checks.
newsitem.headline: Philippines' Ramos back to hospital for checks.

text.p: Philippine President Fidel Ramos was admitted to hospital for the second time in 10 days on Sunday for follow-up tests after being previously stricken with a throat infection, doctors said.
News that 68-year-old Ramos had returned to the Makati Medical Centre for further checks spread after he cancelled some of his engagements for the day.
Some hospital staff initially denied he was back at the centre.
"We are doing more X-rays...because there were many things we saw during the previous check," hospital director Raul Fores said by telephone.
"All the tests are okay ... His blood chemistry is much better," Fores said, adding previous tests had shown Ramos had a "very high" level of cholesterol.
He said the president "had been eating too much," accounting for the high cholesterol.
Fores said he expected Ramos to leave on Monday.

Presidential press undersecretary Marcelo Lagmay said Ramos was re-admitted to the hospital "for a follow-up examination, for a series of X-rays." Lagmay said a medical bulletin on the president's condition was being prepared but no bulletin had been issued up to late Sunday night.
Ramos set off alarm bells on Manila's bourse and corporate boardrooms when he was admitted to the hospital on December 12 and some newspapers reported he had suffered a mild stroke.
He was released three days later after being treated for what Fores said a throat infection.
Ramos resumed a heavy schedule of speaking engagements and other public appearances shortly after he checked out, apparently to scotch the rumours of serious ill-health.
Doctors urged him to slow down, saying he was not young any more, and Ramos cancelled a series of provincial trips.
He told his weekly news conference on Wednesday he was in good health and that jitters in the stock market over his health appeared to be over.

Ramos's hospital spells coincided with a controversy over calls by a citizens' group to amend the constitution to allow him to run for re-election when his six-year term ends in June 1998. The constitution limits a president to a single term.
